title: How the Tortoise Got His Cracked Shell
author: Traditional Igbo Folk Tale
text:
Once upon a time, the birds invited all creatures to a grand feast in the sky. The tortoise, Mbe, longed to attend but had no wings. So he begged feathers from the birds, spun them together into makeshift wings, and soared into the heavens. Once there, Mbe unveiled his name: “All-of-You,” and greedily ate everything before the birds could have their fill. 

 Angered at his selfishness, the birds reclaimed their feathers, leaving Mbe stranded in the sky. Desperate, he telepathically requested his wife on earth to spread soft things for his landing. The birds, still offended, told her to lay out only hard objects. Trusting them, she followed their instructions. Mbe leaped — and crashed painfully against the unforgiving ground. His shell shattered into jagged pieces. In the end, his wife collected the shards and pasted them back together, creating the cracked, beautiful shell tortoises carry to this day.

title: Mbe & All the Wisdom in the World
author: Traditional Igbo Folk Tale
text:
Mbe the Tortoise was known for his sharp mind and clever tricks. One day, he declared: “I shall collect all the wisdom of the world and keep it in one gourd!” He visited animals—elephants, lions, ants—and slyly asked for advice. But instead of giving, they unknowingly whispered their wisdom into his gourd.

Once full, Mbe carried the heavy gourd to the tallest tree and began to climb. But as he ascended, the gourd pressed tightly against his shell, halting his progress. He tried again and again but failed. Then his wise son called out: “Father, tie it to your back,” he said. Mbe did so—but now he could not grab any branches with his arms. He slipped and tumbled down.

Embarrassed, he cracked the gourd, scattering its contents across the earth. Gathering the broken pieces, Mbe realized: wisdom thrives when shared—not hoarded. And so he walked home, a wiser and humbler creature.

title: Omenuko
author: Pita Nwana
text: Omenuko follows the life of Igwegbe Odum, a young man from Arondizuogu who journeys to the Igbo hinterlands and ultimately to the city of Owerri. Charismatic and resourceful, Igwegbe rises through social networks and trade during the 1930s colonial period. He builds relationships with local chiefs, Europeans, and fellow Igbo migrants. The novel explores the tension between tradition and modernity, the struggles of adaptation, and the pains of cultural change. In Pita Nwana’s own words: “Omenuko is not just a story of one man's ambition but a mirror for a people learning to walk new paths.”

title: The Journey of the Igbo Tribe
author: Austine Ogbenna
text: From about 1883 until 1914, Anioma Igbo communities in present-day Delta and Edo States rose in resistance against British colonial rule. Named after the Ekumeku society—a secret, militant order—men and women took the forests and marshes as bases from Ogwashi-Uku to Onicha-Olona. They used guerrilla tactics: ambushes, raids on trade routes, and intelligence networks. Brave leaders like Okumagba rallied fighters, sabotaged colonial forces, and reclaimed lost ground on several occasions. Though battered by superior British weaponry, the movement endured for decades—forcing colonial administrators to compromise, negotiate, and delay full annexation. The Ekumeku Uprising remains an indelible symbol of Igbo resilience and unity.
